description: Comprehensive collection of actual G3 exam questions

questions.question: Which of the following types of fire extinguishers should be used on electrical fires:
questions.reasoning: Class C fire extinguishers are specifically designed for electrical fires. They use non-conductive agents like CO2 or dry chemical to safely suppress fires involving energized electrical equipment without risk of electrical shock to the operator.
questions.notes: Remember: Class A = ordinary combustibles, Class B = flammable liquids, Class C = electrical equipment, Class D = combustible metals

questions.question: A Class D fire extinguisher:
options: Is to be used on fires involving electrical equipment, such as appliances, wiring, circuit breakers and outlets.
Is to be used on fires involving combustible materials such as paper, wood, cardboard, and most plastics.
Is to be used on fires involving chemicals such as combustible metals, such as magnesium, titanium, potassium and sodium.
Is to be used on fires involving cooking oils, trans-fats, or fats in cooking appliances and are typically found in restaurant and cafeteria kitchens.
questions.reasoning: Class D fire extinguishers are specifically designed for combustible metal fires. These metals include magnesium, titanium, potassium, and sodium, which require special dry powder agents that smother the fire without reacting with the burning metal.
questions.notes: Class K is for cooking oils and fats, not Class D

questions.question: A Class C fire extinguisher:
options: Is to be used on fires involving combustible materials such as paper, wood, cardboard, and most plastics.
Is to be used on fires involving electrical equipment, such as appliances, wiring, circuit breakers and outlets.
Is to be used on fires involving flammable or combustible liquids such as gasoline, kerosene, grease and oil
Is to be used on fires involving chemicals such as combustible metals, such as magnesium, titanium, potassium and sodium.
questions.reasoning: Class C fire extinguishers are designed for electrical fires involving equipment like appliances, wiring, circuit breakers, and outlets. They use non-conductive agents to prevent electrical shock during fire suppression.
questions.notes: Always de-energize electrical equipment if safe to do so before fighting the fire

questions.question: What does OHSA stand for:
questions.reasoning: OHSA stands for Occupational Health and Safety Act, which is the provincial legislation in Ontario that sets out the rights and duties of all parties in the workplace regarding health and safety.
questions.csaReference: Ontario Occupational Health and Safety Act, R.S.O. 1990
questions.notes: This is fundamental knowledge for all trades workers in Ontario

questions.question: A Class B fire extinguisher:
options: Is to be used on fires involving cooking oils, trans-fats, or fats in cooking appliances and are typically found in restaurant and cafeteria kitchens.
Is to be used on fires involving combustible materials such as paper, wood, cardboard, and most plastics.
Is to be used on fires involving chemicals such as combustible metals, such as magnesium, titanium, potassium and sodium.
Is to be used on fires involving flammable or combustible liquids such as gasoline, kerosene, grease and oil.
questions.reasoning: Class B fire extinguishers are designed for fires involving flammable and combustible liquids including gasoline, kerosene, grease, and oil. They work by removing oxygen or interrupting the chemical chain reaction of combustion.
questions.notes: Common agents include CO2, dry chemical, and foam

questions.question: A Class A fire extinguisher:
options: Is to be used on fires involving chemicals such as combustible metals, such as magnesium, titanium, potassium and sodium.
Is to be used on fires involving combustible materials such as paper, wood, cardboard, and most plastics.
Is to be used on fires involving flammable or combustible liquids such as gasoline, kerosene, grease and oil.
Is to be used on fires involving cooking oils, trans-fats, or fats in cooking appliances and are typically found in restaurant and cafeteria kitchens.
questions.reasoning: Class A fire extinguishers are designed for ordinary combustibles like paper, wood, cardboard, cloth, and most plastics. These materials leave ash when burned, hence 'A' for 'Ash'.
questions.notes: Water and foam extinguishers are common for Class A fires

questions.question: Where should the nozzle of a fire extinguisher be pointed:
options: at the base of the fire
at the centre of the fire
at the top of the fire
at the side of the fire
questions.reasoning: The nozzle should be aimed at the base of the fire where the fuel source is located. This technique, part of the PASS method (Pull, Aim, Squeeze, Sweep), is most effective in extinguishing the fire by attacking its source.
questions.csaReference: OHSA Fire Safety Training Standards; NFPA 10
questions.notes: PASS method: Pull pin, Aim at base, Squeeze handle, Sweep side to side

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true:
options: workers do not have to wear hard hats on a job site, even if instructed not to do so by the employer
workers must wear the protective clothing that the employer instructs them to wear on the job site
workers do not have to be aware of the contents of the Occupational Health and Safety Act
unnecessary running or rough or boisterous conduct on job sites is NOT prohibited by the Occupational Health and Safety Act
questions.reasoning: Under OHSA, workers have a legal obligation to wear protective equipment required by their employer. This is part of the worker's duties to protect their own health and safety and comply with the Act and regulations.
questions.notes: Workers must use/wear equipment, protective devices or clothing required by employer

questions.question: An employer of a Gas Technician is:
options: responsible for ensuring that technicians are appropriately certified
not responsible for ensuring that safety instruction is provided to workers
responsible for ensuring that workers arrive safely on the job site
responsible for providing all safety clothing to workers
questions.reasoning: Employers must ensure that gas technicians hold valid certificates for the work they perform. This is a regulatory requirement under the Technical Standards and Safety Act and ensures only qualified personnel work on gas equipment.
questions.notes: Employers must verify certification before allowing work on gas equipment

questions.question: Why should garbage and debris be removed from a job site:
options: to prevent possible slips, trips or falls
to reduce the possibility of tool loss in debris
to reduce the likelihood of rodents on the job site
questions.reasoning: The primary safety reason for removing garbage and debris is to prevent slips, trips, and falls, which are among the most common workplace injuries. Good housekeeping is a fundamental safety practice required under OHSA.
questions.notes: Slips, trips, and falls are leading causes of workplace injuries

questions.question: How should an electric drill be disconnected:
options: by pulling on the drill's cord
by pulling the plug at the outlet
by using a pair of insulated channel lock pliers
questions.reasoning: Electric tools should always be disconnected by grasping and pulling the plug at the outlet, not the cord. Pulling on the cord can damage the internal wiring and create electrical hazards.
questions.csaReference: Electrical Safety Code; OHSA Electrical Safety Standards
questions.notes: Never pull on the cord as it can damage the wire connections

questions.question: Convert 40° C to Fahrenheit:
questions.reasoning: Using the formula °F = (°C × 9/5) + 32: (40 × 9/5) + 32 = 72 + 32 = 104°F. This is a basic conversion that gas technicians need to know for reading specifications and manuals.
questions.notes: Formula: °F = (°C × 1.8) + 32

questions.question: Sheathing on copper wire should be removed with:
questions.reasoning: Wire strippers are the proper tool for removing insulation from electrical wires as they are designed to strip the sheathing without damaging the conductor. Using improper tools can nick or damage the wire, creating weak points.
questions.notes: Wire strippers have gauged openings to prevent conductor damage

questions.question: What type of fastener is used to join two electrical wires:
questions.reasoning: Wire nuts (also called marrettes) are the standard approved method for joining electrical wires. They provide both mechanical connection and electrical insulation when properly installed.
questions.notes: Wire nuts must be properly sized for the wire gauge and number of conductors

questions.question: To determine the indicated gas pressure on a "simple" or traditional water-filled "U" tube manometer:
options: read the amount of water column displaced on the pressure side
read the amount of water column displaced on the atmospheric side
read the amount of water column displaced on the pressure side and add it to the amount displaced on the atmospheric side
read the amount of water column displaced on the pressure side and subtract it from the amount displaced on the atmospheric side
questions.reasoning: In a U-tube manometer, the pressure is determined by the total difference in water column height between both sides. You must add the displacement on the pressure side to the displacement on the atmospheric side to get the total pressure reading.
questions.notes: Total pressure = rise on one side + drop on other side

questions.question: A foot has ________ inches and a meter has ______ centimeters.
questions.reasoning: Basic units of measurement: 1 foot = 12 inches and 1 meter = 100 centimeters. These are fundamental conversions that gas technicians must know for reading specifications and performing calculations.
questions.notes: Standard imperial and metric conversions

questions.question: A reading of 7.0" w.c. equals:
questions.reasoning: 7 inches water column equals approximately 1/4 psig (1.72 kPa). The conversion factor is 27.7 inches w.c. = 1 psig, so 7 ÷ 27.7 = 0.25 psig.
questions.notes: 27.7 inches w.c. = 1 psig; 1 inch w.c. = 249 Pa

questions.question: The fastener used to connect a drain hose to a fan coil unit is:
questions.reasoning: Gear clamps (also known as hose clamps) are the proper fastener for securing flexible drain hoses to fan coil units. They provide adjustable, secure connections that can be tightened to prevent leaks.
questions.notes: Gear clamps provide secure, adjustable connections for drain lines

questions.question: Lag shield anchors are generally used to anchor fasteners into:
questions.reasoning: Lag shield anchors are expansion-type anchors specifically designed for use in concrete and masonry. They expand when a lag screw is tightened into them, creating a secure hold in the concrete.
questions.notes: Also called lag shields or concrete anchors

questions.question: What is the volume of a room measuring 16' x 12' x 7':
questions.reasoning: Volume = length × width × height = 16' × 12' × 7' = 1,344 cubic feet. Volume is always expressed in cubic units, not square units.
questions.notes: Volume calculations are essential for combustion air requirements

questions.question: When propane changes from a liquid to a vapour, it expands and its volume increases by:
questions.reasoning: Propane expands approximately 270 times its liquid volume when it vaporizes. This significant expansion ratio is why propane tanks must never be overfilled and why proper relief valves are critical.
questions.csaReference: CSA B149.2 - Propane Storage and Handling Code
questions.notes: 1 gallon of liquid propane = 270 gallons of vapor

questions.question: The flame temperature of propane is approximately:
questions.reasoning: Propane burns at approximately 3,650°F (2,010°C) in air. This high flame temperature makes propane suitable for many heating and industrial applications.
questions.csaReference: Gas Technician Reference Manual - Fuel Properties
questions.notes: Propane flame is hotter than natural gas (3,500°F)

questions.question: The heat content of 1 cubic foot of natural gas is approximately:
questions.reasoning: Natural gas has approximately 1,000 BTU per cubic foot. This is the standard value used for sizing calculations and appliance input ratings in the gas industry.
questions.notes: Exact value varies by gas composition but 1,000 BTU/ft³ is standard

questions.question: What theoretical gas to air ratio is necessary to achieve perfect combustion with an atmospheric natural gas burner:
options: 1 part of natural gas to 10 parts of air
5 parts of natural gas to 5 parts of air
5 parts of natural gas to 15 parts of air
20 parts of natural gas to 1 part of air
questions.reasoning: Natural gas requires approximately 10 parts of air to 1 part of gas for complete combustion (10:1 ratio). This provides the stoichiometric mixture for perfect combustion.
questions.notes: Actual installations use excess air for safety (12-15:1)

questions.question: What is the approximate ignition temperature of natural gas:
questions.reasoning: Natural gas has an ignition temperature of approximately 1,300°F (704°C). This is the minimum temperature required to ignite a natural gas-air mixture.
questions.csaReference: Gas Technician Reference Manual - Fuel Properties
questions.notes: Higher than propane (920-1020°F) ignition temperature

questions.question: When cylinders are being transported, they shall be secured:
options: vertically with chains and straps and a relief valve, in a well-ventilated space
in an upright position with chains and straps and a relief valve, in a well-ventilated space
in an upright position, in a well-ventilated location with the relief valve communicating with the vapour space only
in an upright position, in a well-ventilated location with the relief valve communicating with the liquid space only
questions.reasoning: Propane cylinders must be transported upright in a well-ventilated location with the relief valve communicating with the vapor space only. This ensures the relief valve releases vapor, not liquid, if activated.
questions.notes: Relief valve must be in vapor space to function properly

questions.question: Two undesirable products of incomplete combustion are:
questions.reasoning: Carbon monoxide (CO) and aldehydes are both toxic products of incomplete combustion. These form when there is insufficient oxygen for complete combustion and are serious health hazards.
questions.notes: CO is odorless, colorless, and deadly; aldehydes cause eye irritation

questions.question: Air that is mixed with fuel prior to ignition is called:
questions.reasoning: Primary air is the air that mixes with the gas before combustion occurs, typically drawn in through the venturi of an atmospheric burner. This pre-mixing is essential for proper combustion.
questions.notes: Secondary air is supplied around the flame after ignition

questions.question: Carbon monoxide is a product of:
options: complete combustion with excess air present
incomplete mixing of primary air and secondary air
questions.reasoning: Carbon monoxide (CO) is produced during incomplete combustion when there is insufficient oxygen to fully oxidize the carbon in the fuel to carbon dioxide (CO2).
questions.notes: CO indicates combustion problems requiring immediate attention

questions.question: The ignition temperature of propane is in the range of:
questions.reasoning: Propane has an ignition temperature range of 920°F to 1020°F (493°C to 549°C). This is lower than natural gas, making propane somewhat easier to ignite.
questions.notes: Lower ignition temperature than natural gas (1300°F)

questions.question: The flame temperature of natural gas is approximately:
questions.reasoning: Natural gas burns at approximately 3,500°F (1,927°C) in air. This is slightly cooler than propane but still hot enough for all residential and commercial heating applications.
questions.csaReference: Gas Technician Reference Manual - Fuel Properties
questions.notes: Slightly cooler than propane flame (3,650°F)

questions.question: A luminous flame is caused by:
options: premixing air and fuel prior to combustion
not premixing air and fuel prior to combustion
questions.reasoning: A luminous (yellow) flame occurs when air and fuel are not premixed before combustion. The lack of primary air causes incomplete combustion, producing carbon particles that glow yellow.
questions.notes: Luminous flames indicate insufficient primary air

questions.question: The odourant added to natural gas and propane for detection purposes is:
questions.reasoning: Mercaptan is the odorant added to natural gas and propane to give them their distinctive 'rotten egg' smell. This allows for detection of gas leaks since both gases are naturally odorless.
questions.csaReference: CSA B149.1 - Gas Properties and Safety
questions.notes: Added at ~1 pound per million cubic feet

questions.question: Which of the following are symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning:
questions.reasoning: All listed symptoms are associated with carbon monoxide poisoning. CO binds to hemoglobin preventing oxygen transport, causing headaches, nausea, dizziness, confusion, rapid heart rate, and can be fatal.
questions.notes: CO detectors required near all sleeping areas

questions.question: The relative density of propane in a liquid state is approximately:
questions.reasoning: Liquid propane has a relative density of approximately 0.5 (specific gravity compared to water). This means liquid propane is about half as dense as water and will float on water.
questions.notes: Liquid propane is lighter than water but vapor is heavier than air

questions.question: The specific gravity of propane is:
questions.reasoning: Propane vapor has a specific gravity of 1.52 relative to air. This means propane is heavier than air and will settle in low areas, creating potential hazards in basements or pits.
questions.notes: Being heavier than air, propane settles in low areas

questions.question: Natural gas and propane are composed mainly of:
questions.reasoning: Natural gas (primarily methane CH4) and propane (C3H8) are hydrocarbons composed mainly of carbon and hydrogen atoms. These are the fuel elements that combust to produce heat.
questions.notes: Hydrocarbons: compounds of hydrogen and carbon

questions.question: At 60° F (15.5° C) one pound of liquid propane will produce ______ cubic feet of vapour.
questions.reasoning: One pound of liquid propane produces approximately 8.5 cubic feet of vapor at standard conditions (60°F). This expansion ratio is important for understanding propane system capacity.
questions.notes: 1 gallon liquid = 36.5 ft³ vapor; 1 pound = 8.5 ft³

questions.question: Which of the following are characteristics of carbon monoxide:
options: lighter than air and extremely toxic
questions.reasoning: Carbon monoxide has all these characteristics: it's colorless, tasteless, odorless, combustible, slightly lighter than air (specific gravity 0.97), and extremely toxic.
questions.notes: CO is called the 'silent killer' due to these properties

questions.question: Air is approximately:
questions.reasoning: Air is approximately 78% nitrogen and 21% oxygen (roughly 80/20), with the remaining 1% being other gases. This ratio is important for combustion calculations.
questions.notes: Actual: 78% N2, 21% O2, 1% other gases

questions.question: Is the holder of a valid G.2 certificate certified to work on the carburation system of a propane powered highway vehicle:
options: yes, but only up to the fuel lock-off
no, unless under the direct supervision of a Class "A" mechanic
questions.reasoning: No, G.2 certificate holders are not certified to work on propane vehicle carburation systems. This requires specific automotive propane certification separate from stationary equipment certification.
questions.notes: Vehicle propane systems require separate certification

questions.question: Which of the following observations is true:
options: appliances must be installed with a minimum 24 inches (600 mm) clearance on any side(s) where service is required
appliances must be installed with a minimum 24 inches (600 mm) clearance on every side
appliances installed outdoors must have a minimum 36 inches (600 mm) service clearance to the burner access panel only
appliances must be installed with a minimum 36 inches (1 m) clearance on the side(s) where service is required
questions.reasoning: Appliances must have a minimum 24 inches (600 mm) clearance on sides where service access is required. This ensures adequate space for maintenance and repairs.
questions.notes: Service clearance is different from combustible clearance

questions.question: In the case of a fuel related accident, the Director shall:
options: supply medical assistance for all injuries
prepare a cost estimate for the damages
check the victim's drivers license and proof of insurance
questions.reasoning: The Director has the authority and responsibility to order an appropriate investigation into fuel-related accidents to determine causes and prevent future occurrences.
questions.notes: Director's role is investigative and regulatory, not medical

questions.question: The holder of a G.1 certificate is permitted to work:
options: only on appliances with inputs under 200,000 Btuh
only on appliances with inputs up to 400,000 Btuh
only on appliances with inputs from 400,000 Btuh, to 1,000,000 Btuh
on appliances with any input or heat output phase
questions.reasoning: G.1 certificate holders can work on appliances of any input rating. G.1 is the highest level of gas technician certification with no input limitations.
questions.notes: G.1 = unlimited, G.2 = up to 400,000 BTU/hr, G.3 = activation only

questions.question: What is the expression for the maximum pressure to which any component or portion of the fuel system can be subjected:
questions.reasoning: Maximum working pressure (MWP) is the correct term for the maximum pressure rating of fuel system components. This is the highest pressure the component can safely handle under normal operation.
questions.notes: Components must be rated for MWP of the system

questions.question: An interrupted ignition source:
options: continues to function during the entire period that the flame is present
ceases to function after a trial for ignition period
always functions, regardless if there is a call for heat
questions.reasoning: An interrupted ignition source operates only during the trial for ignition period and then shuts off once the main flame is established. This differs from continuous ignition which operates constantly.
questions.notes: Saves energy compared to continuous pilot systems

questions.question: Any contractor operating under the Gaseous Fuels Regulation is required to:
options: inform all employees to comply with the Act and regulations
monitor all employees to ensure that they comply with the Act and regulations
questions.reasoning: Contractors must register, inform employees of requirements, and monitor compliance with the Act and regulations. All these responsibilities are mandatory for contractors working with gaseous fuels.
questions.notes: Contractors have comprehensive compliance obligations

questions.question: If an Inspector under the Technical Standards and Safety Act issues an order, or if a Director under the Technical Standards and Safety Act refuses to renew a licence, registration or certificate, there is no means of appealing or changing the order or decision.
questions.reasoning: False. The Technical Standards and Safety Act provides appeal mechanisms for orders and decisions. Appeals can be made to the Director and ultimately to the Divisional Court.
questions.csaReference: Technical Standards and Safety Act, 2000 - Appeals
questions.notes: Appeal rights are fundamental to due process

questions.question: Who is responsible for ensuring at the time of installation that there is a proper and adequate venting and air supply for an appliance:
questions.reasoning: The installer is responsible for ensuring proper venting and air supply at the time of installation. This is a critical safety requirement that must be verified before putting any appliance into service.
questions.csaReference: CSA B149.1-25, Section 8 - Venting and Air Supply
questions.notes: Installer must verify code compliance before activation

questions.question: What is the name of the device that is installed either externally or internally to a venting system to extract heat from flue gases:
questions.reasoning: A heat reclaimer is a device designed to extract useable heat from flue gases before they exit the venting system. This improves overall system efficiency by recovering waste heat.
questions.notes: Must not interfere with proper venting operation

questions.question: Which of the following code expressions describes a building used by a gathering of persons for civic, political, travel, religious, social, educational, recreational, or like purposes, or for the consumption of food and drink:
questions.reasoning: An assembly building is defined as one used for gathering of persons for the listed purposes. This classification affects requirements for gas installations due to occupancy loads and safety considerations.
questions.notes: Assembly buildings have specific ventilation and safety requirements

questions.question: What is a Category IV Appliance:
options: an appliance with a power burner
a natural gas or propane-fired water heater or central furnace
an appliance that operates with a positive vent static pressure and a flue loss of less than 17%
an appliance that operates with a positive vent static pressure and a flue loss of not less than 17%
questions.reasoning: A Category IV appliance operates with positive vent static pressure (condensing) and has a flue loss of less than 17%, indicating high efficiency. These require special venting materials for condensate.
questions.notes: Category IV = positive pressure, condensing (high efficiency)

questions.question: Which type of appliance does not have the flue gases mixed with the medium being heated:
questions.reasoning: An indirect fired appliance keeps combustion products separate from the medium being heated through a heat exchanger. This prevents contamination of the heated medium with combustion products.
questions.notes: Direct-fired mixes products with heated medium

questions.question: The holder of a G.2 certificate may install and service gas-fired equipment with inputs up to:
questions.reasoning: G.2 certificate holders are qualified to work on appliances with inputs up to 400,000 BTU/hr (120 kW). This covers most residential and light commercial equipment.
questions.notes: G.2 covers most residential/light commercial work

questions.question: The requalification of refillable propane cylinders used in Ontario must be done in accordance with the procedures for cylinders as established by (the):
questions.reasoning: Transport Canada regulates the requalification of propane cylinders as they are considered dangerous goods. Cylinders must be requalified every 10 years according to Transport Canada standards.
questions.csaReference: Transport Canada - Transportation of Dangerous Goods
questions.notes: Cylinders require requalification every 10 years

questions.question: Which type of pilot burns at low turndown throughout the entire time the burner is in service, whether or not the main burner is firing, except that upon a call for heat, the ignite the main burner fuel:
questions.reasoning: An expanding pilot operates at low fire continuously but expands (increases in size) when there's a call for heat to reliably ignite the main burner. This provides energy savings while maintaining reliability.
questions.notes: Combines efficiency of intermittent with reliability of continuous

questions.question: Where in the B149.1 code book will a person find the table required to size a natural gas piping system made of Schedule 40 pipe and that is to be operated at a pressure of 7" in w.c. (1.75 kPa) up to 14 in w.c., based on a pressure drop of 1" w.c. (250 Pa):
questions.reasoning: Table A.2 in Annex A is used for natural gas systems operating at 7 to 14 inches w.c. with Schedule 40 pipe. This is the standard low-pressure natural gas sizing table.
questions.csaReference: CSA B149.1-25, Annex A - Pipe Sizing Tables
questions.notes: Different tables for different pressures and pipe types

questions.question: Where the Divisional Court hears an appeal of a Director's ruling, the Courts decision is:
options: subject to appeal to the Supreme Court of Ontario
subject to appeal to the Ministry of Consumer and Business Services
subject to appeal to the federal government
questions.reasoning: The Divisional Court's decision on appeals from the Director under the Technical Standards and Safety Act is final. This is the highest level of appeal available for these matters.
questions.csaReference: Technical Standards and Safety Act - Appeal Process
questions.notes: Divisional Court is the final appeal level

questions.question: Venting and air supply requirements are in section _____________ of the B149.1 Code.
questions.reasoning: Section 8 of CSA B149.1 covers all venting and air supply requirements for gas appliances. This is one of the most critical sections for ensuring safe appliance operation.
questions.notes: Section 8 is comprehensive for venting/air supply

questions.question: Gas piping codes are in section __________ of the B149.1 code.
questions.reasoning: Section 6 of CSA B149.1 contains all requirements for gas piping and tubing systems, including materials, installation, testing, and sizing requirements.
questions.notes: Section 6 covers piping and tubing systems

questions.question: The B149.1 Code is used to determine:
options: the best method to clean gas appliances
the gas pressure for gas entering a house
questions.reasoning: CSA B149.1 is the Natural Gas and Propane Installation Code that provides requirements for safe installation of gas appliances, piping, venting, and related equipment.
questions.notes: Primary code for gas installations in Canada

questions.question: The installation of gas burning appliances in recreational vehicles shall be in accordance with:
questions.reasoning: CSA Z240.4.2 is the specific standard for installation of gas systems and appliances in recreational vehicles. This standard addresses the unique requirements of RV installations.
questions.csaReference: CSA Z240.4.2 - Gas Systems in RVs
questions.notes: RVs have special requirements due to mobility

questions.question: A G.2 Technician:
options: may replace a defective residential automatic gas-fired water heater
must advise the owner of the appliance that a plumber is required to replace the defective automatic water heater
may recharge an add-on central air conditioner with refrigerant
may design and install the duct work required for a new installation
questions.reasoning: A G.2 technician may replace a residential gas-fired water heater as it falls within their scope (under 400,000 BTU/hr). They can perform the gas work but may need a plumber for water connections depending on local requirements.
questions.csaReference: O. Reg. 215/01 - G.2 Scope of Work
questions.notes: G.2 can do gas work; plumbing may require separate trade

questions.question: Where in the B149.1 code book will a person find the table required to size a propane tubing system that is to be operated at a pressure of 11" w.c. (2.7 kPa), based on a pressure drop of 1" w.c. (250 Pa):
questions.reasoning: Table B.7 in Annex B is used for propane tubing systems operating at 11 inches w.c. This table provides sizing for low-pressure propane tubing installations.
questions.csaReference: CSA B149.1-25, Annex B - Propane Sizing Tables
questions.notes: Annex B for propane, different tables for pipe vs tubing

questions.question: What is the term for a device used to control and maintain within acceptable limits, a uniform outlet pressure:
questions.reasoning: A pressure regulator is the device that controls and maintains uniform outlet pressure regardless of inlet pressure variations. This is essential for safe appliance operation.
questions.notes: Regulators protect appliances from overpressure

questions.question: Every person commits an offense against the TSS Act who:
options: fails to comply with an authorization or
questions.reasoning: All listed actions constitute offenses under the Technical Standards and Safety Act: contravening the Act, making false statements, and failing to comply with authorizations are all punishable offenses.
questions.csaReference: Technical Standards and Safety Act - Offenses
questions.notes: Violations can result in fines and/or imprisonment

questions.question: The Minister may make orders:
questions.reasoning: The Minister has broad authority under the Act to make orders regarding inspector qualifications, inspection procedures, fuel grades, and other safety-related matters.
questions.csaReference: Technical Standards and Safety Act - Ministerial Powers
questions.notes: Minister has comprehensive regulatory authority

questions.question: What is meant by "purging" a pipe system:
options: painting the pipe, or identifying it with markings or yellow bands (tape)
reaming the ends of the pipe to eliminate all burrs
filling the piping with nitrogen or carbon dioxide to ensure there is no air trapped within
replacing the existing (gaseous or liquid) fluid in the piping or tubing with a desired fluid
questions.reasoning: Purging means replacing the existing contents of piping with the desired fluid, typically removing air from gas lines before use or removing gas before service. This is a critical safety procedure.
questions.notes: Essential safety procedure before activation or service

questions.question: A "relief device" in a piping system is a/an:
options: device used to divert the flow of gas in the event of a runaway condition
device used to relieve high temperatures that could cause over-pressure
device designed to open to prevent a rise of gas pressure in excess of a specified value due to emergency or abnormal conditions
assembly installed in the outlet plenum of a forced air furnace, which opens in the event of high static pressure
questions.reasoning: A relief device is designed to open automatically to prevent pressure from exceeding safe limits due to emergency or abnormal conditions. This is a critical safety component in gas systems.
questions.notes: Prevents dangerous overpressure conditions

questions.question: Which of the following is covered in the B149.1 Natural Gas and Propane Installation Code?
options: installation of feedstock gas in chemical plants
questions.reasoning: The B149.1 code covers installation of gas venting systems for appliances. It does not cover industrial processes, refineries, or distribution pipelines which have separate regulations.
questions.notes: B149.1 covers appliance installations, not industrial/utility

questions.question: During an inspection by a TSSA Inspector, every person shall:
options: assist the inspector, but not be responsible to produce anything
assist the inspector and produce anything where necessary
questions.reasoning: During TSSA inspections, persons must assist the inspector and produce any required documentation or items. This cooperation is legally required to ensure safety compliance.
questions.csaReference: Technical Standards and Safety Act - Inspection Powers
questions.notes: Legal obligation to cooperate with inspections

questions.question: Which type of appliance is constructed so that all the combustion air is supplied directly from, and the products of combustion are vented directly to the outdoors by independent enclosed passageways connected directly to the appliance:
questions.reasoning: A direct vent appliance has sealed combustion with separate intake and exhaust pipes directly connected to outdoors. This isolates combustion from indoor air completely.
questions.notes: Most efficient and safe venting method

questions.question: Vent sizing for central heating furnaces, boilers and water heaters that have an input of less than 400,000 Btuh (120 kW) shall be provided in accordance with:
options: clauses 8.2 & 8.3 of the B149.1 Natural Gas and Propane Installation Code
clause 8.4 of the B149.1 Natural Gas and Propane Installation Code
clause 8.14 of the B149.1 Natural Gas and Propane Installation Code
Annex C of the B149.1 Natural Gas and Propane Installation Code
questions.reasoning: Annex C of B149.1 contains the venting tables and sizing methods for Category I appliances under 400,000 BTU/hr. This includes most residential furnaces, boilers, and water heaters.
questions.notes: Annex C has comprehensive venting tables

questions.question: The maximum fine for an individual found guilty under the Technical Standards and Safety Act is:
questions.reasoning: Under the Technical Standards and Safety Act, individuals can face maximum penalties of $50,000 in fines and/or one year imprisonment for violations.
questions.csaReference: Technical Standards and Safety Act - Penalties
questions.notes: Corporations face higher maximum fines

questions.question: An appliance shall be installed with a minimum service clearance of:
questions.reasoning: Appliances require a minimum service clearance of 24 inches (0.6 m) on sides requiring service access. This ensures adequate space for maintenance and repairs.
questions.notes: Service clearance ensures safe maintenance access

questions.question: Which word describes the phrase "acceptable to the authority having jurisdiction":
questions.reasoning: "Approved" is the standard term meaning acceptable to the authority having jurisdiction. This indicates compliance with applicable codes and standards as determined by the regulatory authority.
questions.notes: AHJ determines what is approved for use

questions.question: Which testing agency is NOT recognized for certifying propane appliances in the province of Ontario:
questions.reasoning: Transport Canada regulates transportation of dangerous goods, not appliance certification. CSA, UL, and ULC are recognized certification bodies for gas appliances in Ontario.
questions.notes: Transport Canada handles cylinders, not appliances

questions.question: Which organization is responsible for administering fuel regulations for the installation of gas appliances in Ontario:
questions.reasoning: The Technical Standards and Safety Authority (TSSA) is the regulatory body responsible for administering and enforcing fuel safety regulations in Ontario, including gas appliance installations.
questions.notes: TSSA is Ontario's safety regulator

questions.question: What is the B149.1 Natural Gas and Propane Installation Code term for an automatic valve that has a closing time of less than 5 seconds upon being de-energized:
questions.reasoning: A safety shut-off valve is defined as an automatic valve with a closing time of less than 5 seconds when de-energized. This rapid closure is essential for safety in emergency situations.
questions.csaReference: CSA B149.1-25 - Safety Shut-off Valve Definition
questions.notes: Fast closure prevents gas flow in emergencies

questions.question: If a heat exchanger is found to be cracked on a residential furnace, a gas technician shall:
options: shut off the gas supply and inform the gas distributor of the situation immediately
shut off the gas supply and inform the Technical Standards and Safety Authority of the situation immediately
shut off the gas supply and inform the Ontario Fire Marshal's Office of the situation immediately
shut off the gas supply and inform the Department of Labour of the situation immediately
questions.reasoning: When a cracked heat exchanger is found, the technician must shut off the gas supply and immediately notify the gas distributor (utility company), who will red-tag the appliance as unsafe.
questions.notes: Cracked heat exchanger = immediate hazard requiring shutdown

questions.question: Propane cylinders manufactured in Canada after January 1, 1993 are to be built and marked to the specifications of:
options: The Boiler and Pressure Vessels Code
The Ministry of Consumer and Business Services
questions.reasoning: Transport Canada regulates the manufacture and certification of propane cylinders as they are classified as pressure vessels for dangerous goods. Cylinders must meet TC specifications.
questions.csaReference: Transport Canada - Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations
questions.notes: TC stamp required on all cylinders

questions.question: A certificate holder must inform the Technical Standards and Safety Authority of a change of address within _________ days.
questions.reasoning: Certificate holders must notify TSSA of address changes within 15 days. This ensures TSSA can maintain current records and contact information for all certified technicians.
questions.notes: Timely notification ensures proper regulatory communication

questions.question: The current required to operate a device rated for 1500 watts at 120 volts is:
questions.reasoning: Using Ohm's law: I = P/V = 1500W / 120V = 12.5 amps. This calculation is essential for proper circuit sizing and electrical safety.
questions.notes: P = V × I, therefore I = P ÷ V

questions.question: When checking an electrical circuit and an analog meter reads ∞, what does this indicate?
questions.reasoning: An infinity (∞) reading on an ohmmeter indicates infinite resistance, meaning an open circuit with no continuity. Current cannot flow through an open circuit.
questions.notes: Infinity = open circuit, zero = closed circuit

questions.question: The resistance reading across a good fuse will be:
questions.reasoning: A good fuse should show 0 ohms (or very close to zero) resistance, indicating continuity. This means the fuse element is intact and current can flow through it.
questions.notes: 0 ohms = good fuse, infinity = blown fuse

questions.question: Consider a series electrical circuit connected to a 120VAC power source. The circuit contains two resistors connected in series: R1 with a resistance of 10 ohms and R2 with a resistance of 20 ohms. The current flows from the power source through R1, then through R2, and returns to the power source. Draw or visualize this series circuit. What is the total current in this series circuit?
questions.reasoning: In a series circuit with 120V and total resistance of 30Ω (10Ω + 20Ω), current I = V/R = 120V / 30Ω = 4 amps. Current is the same throughout a series circuit.
questions.notes: Question rewritten to include series circuit diagram description for student visualization

questions.question: Referring to the series circuit with 120VAC power source and two resistors (R1 = 10 ohms, R2 = 20 ohms) connected in series, what is the total resistance in the circuit?
questions.reasoning: In a series circuit, total resistance is the sum of individual resistances: RT = R1 + R2 = 10Ω + 20Ω = 30Ω.
questions.notes: Question rewritten to include circuit component values for student visualization

questions.question: In a series circuit with 120VAC power source and two resistors (R1 = 10 ohms, R2 = 20 ohms), where the current flows through R1 first then R2, what is the voltage drop across R1?
questions.reasoning: Using Ohm's law with current of 4A through R1 (10Ω): V = I × R = 4A × 10Ω = 40 volts. Voltage divides proportionally to resistance in series circuits.
questions.notes: Question rewritten to include circuit description for student visualization

questions.question: In a series circuit with 120VAC power source and two resistors (R1 = 10 ohms, R2 = 20 ohms), where the current flows through R1 first then R2, what is the voltage drop across R2?
questions.reasoning: Using Ohm's law with current of 4A through R2 (20Ω): V = I × R = 4A × 20Ω = 80 volts. This plus the 40V across R1 equals the 120V supply.
questions.notes: Question rewritten to include circuit description for student visualization

questions.question: Consider a complete series circuit with a 120VAC power source connected to two resistors in series (R1 = 10 ohms and R2 = 20 ohms). The circuit forms a closed loop from the positive terminal through R1, then R2, and back to the negative terminal. What is the total voltage drop across the circuit in this figure?
questions.reasoning: The total voltage drop across the circuit equals the supply voltage of 120 volts. The sum of individual voltage drops (40V + 80V) equals the source voltage.
questions.notes: Question rewritten to include complete circuit description for student visualization

questions.question: Which of the following statements concerning ohmmeters is correct?
options: An ohmmeter must never be connected to a live circuit.
An ohmmeter must always be connected to a live circuit.
The ohmmeter scale on an analog meter is divided into equal increments.
Using an ohmmeter requires the connection of only one lead.
questions.reasoning: An ohmmeter must never be connected to a live circuit as it supplies its own voltage for resistance measurement. Connecting to a live circuit can damage the meter and create safety hazards.
questions.notes: Always verify circuit is de-energized before resistance testing

questions.question: Which of the following will most digital ohmmeters display when connected across an open circuit?
questions.reasoning: Digital ohmmeters typically display 'OL' (overload or over limit) when measuring an open circuit, indicating resistance beyond the meter's measuring range (infinite resistance).
questions.notes: OL = Over Limit = open circuit

questions.question: As the current increases in a conductor the magnetic field around the conductor:
questions.reasoning: The magnetic field strength around a conductor is directly proportional to the current flowing through it. As current increases, the magnetic field increases proportionally.
questions.notes: Basis for transformer and motor operation

questions.question: Which statement is correct concerning a parallel circuit?
options: The total resistance of the circuit is the sum of each individual resistance in the circuit
The total resistance of the circuit will be less than the smallest resistance in the circuit
The current reading will be the same no matter where it is taken in the circuit
Voltage drop across each load is less than the voltage supplied
questions.reasoning: In a parallel circuit, the total resistance is always less than the smallest individual resistance. This is because parallel paths provide multiple routes for current flow.

questions.question: On a 120 volt receptacle, the ground connection terminals are:
questions.reasoning: The ground connection on a receptacle is identified by green color (or green with yellow stripe). The ground terminal may also have a green screw.
questions.notes: Green = ground, white = neutral, black/red = hot

questions.question: The total current in a parallel circuit (i.e. taken at source) will be:
options: the sum of the current passing through each branch circuit
questions.reasoning: In a parallel circuit, the total current from the source equals the sum of all branch currents. This follows Kirchhoff's Current Law.

questions.question: The resistance reading across a blown fuse will be:
questions.reasoning: A blown fuse shows infinite resistance (open circuit) because the fuse element is broken, preventing current flow. The meter will read infinity or OL.
questions.notes: Blown fuse = open circuit = infinite resistance

questions.question: When a voltage measurement is being taken on a DC circuit, the needle on the analog meter moves to below zero on the scale. What does this indicate?
options: The battery in the meter is dead.
questions.reasoning: When an analog meter needle goes below zero on DC voltage measurement, it indicates reversed polarity - the test leads are connected backwards (positive to negative and vice versa).
questions.notes: DC measurements are polarity sensitive

questions.question: The equivalent resistance of two 10 Ohm resistors connected in parallel is:
questions.reasoning: For two equal resistors in parallel: RT = R/2 = 10Ω/2 = 5Ω. The parallel combination always results in less resistance than any individual resistor.
questions.notes: Equal resistors in parallel: RT = R/n

questions.question: The branch electrical circuit to a heating appliance may be used to supply power to:
options: other electrical devices as long as the total amp draw is less than 15 amps.
accessories necessary for the safe operation of the appliance
other electrical devices as long as a 20 amp fuse is installed.
questions.reasoning: The dedicated circuit for a heating appliance may only supply power to accessories necessary for safe appliance operation (controls, pumps, fans). It cannot be shared with other loads.
questions.notes: Dedicated circuit ensures reliable appliance operation

questions.question: Which statement is correct?
options: A clamp-on ammeter must never be used on a live circuit
A clamp-on ammeter must pinch the wire or terminal for a proper reading.
A clamp-on ammeter must be clamped around one conductor only.
A clamp-on ammeter must be clamped around both conductors.
questions.reasoning: A clamp-on ammeter must be clamped around only one conductor to measure current. Clamping around multiple conductors will cause magnetic fields to cancel, resulting in no reading.
questions.notes: One conductor only for accurate current measurement

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
options: Direct current electricity alternates polarity (i.e. +/-) regularly
Direct current flows from the positive terminal to the negative terminal
Direct current measurements are not polarity sensitive (i.e. black test probe must be on negative terminal)
questions.reasoning: Direct current (DC) flows in one direction from positive to negative terminal. This is conventional current flow, though electrons actually flow from negative to positive.
questions.notes: DC has constant polarity, AC alternates

questions.question: Electromotive Force is another expression for:
questions.reasoning: Electromotive Force (EMF) is another term for voltage - the electrical pressure that causes current to flow through a circuit. It's measured in volts.
questions.notes: EMF = voltage = electrical potential difference

questions.question: If a co-worker is suffering a shock from an electrical circuit and cannot let go of the circuit, the first action to take is to:
options: call the emergency response phone number.
give the co-worker a quick push to free him or her from the circuit.
disconnect the power to the electrical circuit.
grab the closest object and shove the person away from the circuit.
questions.reasoning: The first priority is to disconnect power to prevent continued electrocution. Never touch the victim directly as you may also be shocked. De-energize the circuit immediately.
questions.notes: Never touch electrocution victim until power is off

questions.question: If resistance is constant in a resistive circuit and there is a voltage surge, the current:
questions.reasoning: According to Ohm's law (I = V/R), if voltage increases and resistance remains constant, current must increase proportionally. They have a direct relationship.
questions.notes: I = V/R; if V increases and R is constant, I increases

questions.question: One motor horsepower equals approximately ____ watts.
questions.reasoning: One horsepower equals approximately 746 watts (rounded to 750W for practical calculations). This conversion is essential for electrical load calculations.
questions.notes: 1 HP = 746 watts (use 750W for calculations)

questions.question: If the voltage drop across a load in a simple circuit is not the applied voltage, this indicates:
options: a poor connection in the circuit.
there is more than one load wired in parallel with the tested load.
questions.reasoning: In a simple circuit with one load, the entire supply voltage should drop across that load. If not, there's resistance elsewhere (poor connection) causing additional voltage drop.
questions.notes: Poor connections create unwanted resistance and voltage drop

questions.question: Which of the following statements concerning electrical conductors is correct?
options: Armoured cable can only be used outdoors.
A gouge in an electrical wire should be repaired with electrical tape.
A junction box connector approved for the box and wire type must be used.
Wires should be bent around terminal connection screws in a counter clockwise direction.
questions.reasoning: Proper junction box connectors approved for the specific box and wire type must be used to ensure safe, code-compliant connections. This prevents damage to conductors and ensures proper grounding.
questions.notes: Always use approved connectors for safety

questions.question: What is the Btuh output of an electric heater rated at 15 kW:
questions.reasoning: To convert kW to BTU/hr: 15 kW × 3,412 BTU/kWh = 51,180 BTU/hr. The conversion factor 3,412 is standard for electrical to thermal energy.
questions.notes: 1 kW = 3,412 BTU/hr

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
options: # 14 AWG electrical wire is approved for use on 30 amp circuits.
# 14 AWG electrical wire always stranded core for flexible use.
# 14 AWG electrical wire is approved for use on 15 amp circuits.
# 14 AWG electrical wire always has two conductor wires.
questions.reasoning: #14 AWG wire is rated for 15 amp circuits maximum. This is a standard electrical code requirement for residential wiring to prevent overheating.

questions.question: How far into a junction box must conductors extend:
questions.reasoning: Electrical code requires conductors to extend at least 6 inches into a junction box to provide adequate length for making connections and future servicing.
questions.notes: 6 inches ensures adequate working length

questions.question: Which of the following statements concerning ammeters is correct?
options: An ammeter measures resistance in ohms.
An in-line ammeter must be connected across the load.
An in-line ammeter must be connected in series with the load.
The jaws of a clamp-on ammeter must pinch the conductor.
questions.reasoning: An in-line ammeter must be connected in series with the load to measure current flow through the circuit. Connecting in parallel would create a short circuit.
questions.notes: Series connection required for current measurement

questions.question: If the scale on a mechanical drawing is 1/8" - 1'0" then a line measuring 4" in length is actually:
questions.reasoning: With scale 1/8" = 1', a 4" line represents: 4" ÷ (1/8") = 32 units of 1' = 32 feet. Each 1/8" on the drawing represents 1 foot actual.
questions.notes: Scale 1/8" = 1' means multiply drawing by 96

questions.question: Using the CSA B149.1 vent terminal height graph where the X-axis shows roof pitch (rise/run) from 0 to 24/12 and the Y-axis shows minimum vent height in feet from 0 to 12 feet, find the minimum vent height for a natural gas fired appliance on a roof with a 12/12 pitch (45-degree angle) and no obstructions. The graph shows a stepped line that increases as roof pitch increases, with specific heights at common roof pitches.
questions.reasoning: According to CSA B149.1 venting requirements, a 12/12 pitch (45-degree) roof requires a minimum 4-foot vent height above the roof for proper draft and clearance from the roof surface.
questions.csaReference: CSA B149.1-25, Figure 8.1 - Vent Terminal Heights
questions.notes: Question rewritten to include graph description for student visualization

questions.question: T F The boiling point of water is 212°F or 100°C.
questions.reasoning: True. Water boils at 212°F (Fahrenheit) or 100°C (Celsius) at standard atmospheric pressure. These are fundamental reference points for temperature scales.
questions.notes: At sea level standard pressure

questions.question: Mechanical drawings are used to:
options: give the building address, show the equipment location, piping layout, duct sizing and duct layout
give the building address, locate the building on the site, location of adjacent structures, piping layout, and show equipment location
give the building address, indicate the building size, show its elevations, list the mechanical equipment, and show its location, show all permits
give the building address, show the owner's name, installer's name, permit numbers, the equipment list and the warranty
questions.reasoning: Mechanical drawings show equipment location, piping layout, duct sizing and layout - all the technical details needed for HVAC system installation. They focus on mechanical systems, not site plans or permits.
questions.notes: Mechanical drawings detail HVAC system components

questions.question: Using the CSA B149.1 vent terminal height graph where the X-axis shows roof pitch (rise/run) from 0 to 24/12 and the Y-axis shows minimum vent height in feet from 0 to 12 feet, find the minimum vent height for a natural gas fired appliance on a roof with a 14/12 pitch (approximately 50-degree angle) and no obstructions. The graph shows a stepped line that increases as roof pitch increases.
questions.reasoning: A 14/12 pitch roof (steeper than 45 degrees) requires approximately 5 feet minimum vent height according to B149.1 venting requirements to ensure proper clearance and draft.
questions.csaReference: CSA B149.1-25, Figure 8.1 - Vent Terminal Heights
questions.notes: Question rewritten to include graph description for student visualization

questions.question: Equipment specifications indicate mainly:
options: dimensions required to install the appliance, weight of the equipment, electrical characteristics, size and location of the vent outlet, piping inlet size, model number
size of building required to accommodate the equipment, parts list, weight of equipment, installation clearances, piping outlet size, serial number
address of installation, required appliance output, electrical characteristics, weight of equipment, branch piping size, model number

physical dimensions required to install the appliance, weight of the equipment, amount of fuel consumed, CO content of the fuel consumed, electrical characteristics, size and location of the vent outlet
questions.reasoning: Equipment specifications provide installation dimensions, weight, electrical requirements, vent outlet size/location, gas inlet size, and model number - all critical installation information.
questions.notes: Specifications contain essential installation data

questions.question: A "bill of materials" is a:
options: list sent by the manufacturer as a check list of the materials delivered to the site
purchase order copy including the materials which were ordered
list indicating the materials required to complete an installation
list of all the materials used manufacturing the equipment
questions.reasoning: A bill of materials is a comprehensive list of all materials, components, and supplies required to complete an installation project. It's used for planning and procurement.
questions.notes: BOM ensures all necessary materials are available

questions.question: Equipment wiring diagrams indicate which of the following?
options: supply voltage, wire size from panel, fuse size, internal wiring
supply voltage, internal wiring, location of controls, field wiring
supply voltage, fuse size, type of disconnect switch, factory wiring
supply voltage, size of control wiring, location of gas valve, factory wiring
questions.reasoning: Wiring diagrams show supply voltage requirements, internal (factory) wiring, control locations, and field wiring connections. They guide proper electrical installation and troubleshooting.
questions.notes: Solid lines = factory wiring, dashed = field wiring

questions.question: A broken or dotted line on a manufacturer's wiring diagram normally indicates:
questions.reasoning: Broken or dotted lines on wiring diagrams indicate field-installed wiring that the technician must install, as opposed to solid lines which show factory-installed wiring.
questions.notes: Technician responsible for field wiring connections

questions.question: To correct a symptom such as a fluctuating flame, a technician should first:
options: notify the local utility or fuel supplier
exchange the appliance and contact the manufacturer
questions.reasoning: The first step in troubleshooting should always be consulting the manufacturer's instructions for specific troubleshooting guides and adjustment procedures for that equipment.
questions.notes: Manufacturer's instructions are the primary reference

questions.question: When asked to remove footwear at the door of a customer, the best approach is:
options: to comply and take off your boots and leave them at the door
to refuse and push past the customer in the interest of safety
to offer to wear boot covers after explaining that they are safety boots
to remove your boots and wear slippers instead
questions.reasoning: The professional approach is to explain that safety boots are required PPE but offer to wear boot covers to protect the customer's floors. This balances safety requirements with customer service.
questions.csaReference: Customer Service Best Practices; OHSA PPE Requirements
questions.notes: Safety boots are mandatory PPE on job sites

questions.question: When listening to a customer's concerns, the best approach is:
options: to explain in terms they will understand
questions.reasoning: Effective customer service requires being sympathetic to concerns, taking notes for accuracy, and explaining technical issues in understandable terms. All these practices build trust and ensure clear communication.
questions.notes: Good communication is essential for customer satisfaction

questions.question: Of the following list which choice represents a positive customer relations action:
options: Using the washing machine as a work bench
Cleaning up waste created by your actions
Advising them to call head office for answers
questions.reasoning: Cleaning up after your work shows professionalism and respect for the customer's property. It's a basic expectation of professional service work.
questions.notes: Leave work area as clean or cleaner than found

questions.question: The fittings used to protect pipe threads during shipment are not allowed to be used in installations because they:
options: have no shoulder to put a pipe wrench on
questions.reasoning: Shipping protection fittings have running threads (straight threads) rather than tapered pipe threads, making them unsuitable for gas-tight connections required in installations.
questions.notes: Only NPT tapered threads approved for gas

questions.question: Propane piping of 200 ft. (61 m) in length or less operating at a pressure over 2 psig (14 kPa) but not more than 33 psig (230 kPa) shall be tested at a minimum of:
questions.reasoning: Propane piping in this pressure range must be tested at 50 psig for 60 minutes minimum. Higher test pressure ensures system integrity for propane's higher operating pressures.
questions.notes: Test pressure = 1.5 times operating pressure minimum

questions.question: A manual shut off valve used for natural gas shall be:
options: a lubricated eccentric type, rated for the pressure or temperature to which it will be subjected.
a gate type valve rated for the pressure or temperature to which it will be subjected, made of stainless steel, rated for the pressure or temperature to which it will be subjected.
a plug, ball or eccentric type rated for the pressure or temperature to which it will be subjected
questions.reasoning: Manual shut-off valves for gas must be plug, ball, or eccentric type (quarter-turn valves) rated for system pressure and temperature. Gate valves are not approved for gas service.
questions.notes: Quarter-turn valves provide positive shut-off

questions.question: For a piping system supplying an appliance having a rated input under 400,000 Btuh (120 kW), the supply line and branch line to the appliance may be purged:
options: at the main burner of a furnace.
by removing the drip pocket of the appliance.
into the combustion chamber of the appliance.
at a readily accessible burner such as the open top burner of a gas range.
questions.reasoning: Small systems under 400,000 BTU/hr may be purged through a readily accessible burner like a range top burner where gas can be safely ignited. This is the approved method for small residential systems.
questions.notes: Larger systems require outdoor purging

questions.question: Pipe fittings in gas piping systems shall be made of:
questions.reasoning: Gas pipe fittings must be made of steel or malleable iron. Cast iron is too brittle and not approved for gas service due to potential for cracking.
questions.notes: Cast iron is prohibited for gas fittings

questions.question: When can plastic piping be used indoors?
options: only when tested prior to concealment
only if it is under 1 inch (25 mm) in diameter
only with the permission of the local utility or the fuel supplier
questions.reasoning: Plastic piping is never permitted for indoor gas installations. It's only approved for outdoor underground use with proper protection and transition fittings.
questions.notes: Plastic only for outdoor underground installations

questions.question: Are individual shut off valves for appliances in recreation vehicles necessary?
options: only where the cylinder is not readily accessible.
not if a quick disconnect fitting is used.
questions.reasoning: Yes, individual shut-off valves are required for each appliance in recreational vehicles to allow isolation for service and emergency shutdown.
questions.notes: Each appliance needs individual isolation
